discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
As it happens, I actually found some use of `split_find` in my development and I noticed that it is a little inconvenient to have the `s` in the `_spec` variant types to be the first argument, because the equation for `s` is the most meaningful and the equation-generating case starts counting from the right. This leads to something like: 
```
case def_s : _ _ _ _ / (split_find_nth x has_p) => [/= nz s1 s2 nz_p Ns2].
```
On the other hand, the existing split lemmas have the same issue.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: @chdoc, `s` is non-discriminant because it is an index which is a variable, so putting it last would screw up the search for another index.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: If these lemmas are "generalizations" of findP, why do they take `has p s` as argument rather than replacing it?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Since this is basically `find_split` with the additional replacement of `nth x0 s i`, maybe this should be called `find_split_nth`. After all, splitting is still the main thing this lemma does.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
The comment is wrong I guess, they are generalizations of `splitP`, from `path`!
And I refactored the proof of `splitP` to witness it.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Well, at least I spotted that something was amiss :slightly_smiling_face:
